entries.content: When handling an objection like 'I need to think about it,' ask, 'What specifically do you need to think about?' to uncover the real reason.
Acknowledge the customer's concern before responding to an objection: 'I understand exactly where you're coming from...'
Use a 'feel, felt, found' structure to address common objections by relating to others who felt the same way but found success.
Reframe a price objection by comparing the cost to the potential value or return on investment the customer will receive.
Turn an objection into a clarifying question to better understand the customer's underlying concern.
When a customer says 'it's too expensive,' respond by asking 'Compared to what?' to understand their frame of reference.
Isolate the objection to ensure it's the *only* thing preventing the sale. 'So, if we can address this, is that the only concern?'
Use silence after asking a question to handle an objection; it prompts the other person to elaborate.
Confirm you've fully understood the objection by restating it in your own words before offering a solution.
Handle the 'I need to talk to my partner/boss' objection by offering to schedule a brief follow-up meeting including them.
Address skepticism about results by providing specific case studies or testimonials from similar customers.
If the objection is 'I don't have time,' focus on how the solution will *save* them time or improve efficiency.
View objections not as rejections, but as requests for more information or clarification.
Maintain composure and empathy when receiving an objection; stay calm and understanding.
